For reference, the yield of 8.2 liters is equal to approximately 16.22 grams, which is almost exactly 2 standard 8 gram whipped cream chargers, which when purchased from Greatwhip at a quantity of 100, in total cost approximately $1.08. This can be confirmed by the fact that a standard whipped cream charger fills a balloon to a standard size, and there are 2 of them shown in the video. Therefore, if you want N2O, listen to Nile and buy it separately.
If you want to get high on it, I would recommend GreatWhip, as that is the most documented, and likely very safe. BUT: Be VERY careful when breathing it in, and take at LEAST 1 DEEP breath of air between nitrous inhales. Though 2 or 3 deep breaths are recommended.
Yes, I have experience with nitrous. And yes, for legal reasons, that is a joke. I do not condone the abuse of nitrous oxide. Seriously, you can die if you're not very careful. And do NOT combine it with ANY depressants, as that will make the danger significantly higher. But it's your body.

Nitrous is actually used in lower doses at the dentist. Whippets, or recreational nitrous oxide is just pure nitrous oxide, usually inhaled from a balloon or a professional whipped cream dispenser that you can put nitrous oxide cartridges in. But at the dentist and in other medical settings, they usually start with a mix of 50/50 nitrous/oxygen and then bring it up to 70/30 nitrous/oxygen. But of course you're inhaling it for much longer since a single nitrous oxide cartridge for whipped cream will last maybe 1 minute, and at the dentist, you get it for anywhere from 30 minutes to several hours, depending how long you're there and what's being done. But it's just as strong at the dentist.

I would also like to mention, regarding the reason nitrous oxide is used in whipped cream, that it doesn't set off the same receptors on the tongue as, say, the carbon dioxide used in soda, which sets off pain receptors. A soda siphon full of water charged with nitrous oxide will be just as fizzy, but taste almost flat on the tongue.
And so you know, there are drinks that use soda water and milk, like phosphates and egg creams, and they don't curdle because of the cold temperature and possibly also the dilution of the milk.
I know as a chemist, one tends to avoid putting chemicals in ones mouth as a standard safety measure, but when it's food safe, such observations can lead to some interesting finds!

A factory town in Germany was nearly wiped out when a huge quantity of AN was being broken up using dynamite!

No one knew that pure AN was an explosive at the time, although ANFO was known.
